result.markdown:
--- title: DataFrames.jl Cheat Sheet description: | A WIP cheat sheet for working with DataFrames.jl date: '2024-02-14' format: html: code-fold: false execute: warning: false --- A cheat sheet for using [DataFrames.jl](https://dataframes.juliadata.org/stable/). This is a work in progress and will (hopefully) be continuously updated/modified. # Load Pkgs and Read in data ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} using CSV using DataFrames using Statistics using Chain #note that the missingstring arg will read in any "NA" strings as missings penguins = CSV.read(download("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2020/2020-07-28/penguins.csv"), DataFrame, missingstring="NA" ); ``` ::: # Check Properties of data ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.julia .cell-code} size(penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ``` (344, 8) ``` ::: ::: see the first 3 rows ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.julia .cell-code} first(penguins, 3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ```{=html}
3×8 DataFrame
Rowspeciesislandbill_length_mmbill_depth_mmflipper_length_mmbody_mass_gsexyear
String15String15Float64?Float64?Int64?Int64?String7?Int64
1AdelieTorgersen39.118.71813750male2007
2AdelieTorgersen39.517.41863800female2007
3AdelieTorgersen40.318.01953250female2007
``` ::: ::: get the column names of a dataframe ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.julia .cell-code} names(penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ``` 8-element Vector{String}: "species" "island" "bill_length_mm" "bill_depth_mm" "flipper_length_mm" "body_mass_g" "sex" "year" ``` ::: ::: nb we could also convert these to `Symbol` via: ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.julia .cell-code} Symbol.(names(penguins)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ``` 8-element Vector{Symbol}: :species :island :bill_length_mm :bill_depth_mm :flipper_length_mm :body_mass_g :sex :year ``` ::: ::: If we want to get the column types, we can do the following: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.julia .cell-code} eltype.(eachcol(penguins)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` 8-element Vector{Type}: String15 String15 Union{Missing, Float64} Union{Missing, Float64} Union{Missing, Int64} Union{Missing, Int64} Union{Missing, String7} Int64 ``` ::: ::: # Subsetting Rows In general, we'll want to use the `subset()` or `subset!()` functions to subset rows in a dataframe (`subset!()` is the in-place version) The syntax is a little wonky, and it tends to involve passing a symbol into an anonymous function that is then broadcast. For instance, the following will keep only the Chinstrap penguins: ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.julia .cell-code} subset(penguins, :species => s -> s .== "Chinstrap") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ```{=html}
68×8 DataFrame

57ChinstrapDream45.216.61913250female2009

``` ::: ::: And it's straightforward to pass multiple conditions to the function: ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.julia .cell-code} subset(penguins, :species => s -> s .== "Chinstrap", :bill_length_mm => b -> b .> 50, skipmissing=true) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ```{=html}

If there are missing values in a column that's being filtered on, this will throw an error We can also drop rows with any missing data via `dropmissing(df)` ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.julia .cell-code} dropmissing(penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # Creating New Columns We can create new columns using the `transform()` function (or `transform!()` for in-place). The general pattern here is that creating a column takes 3 components: 1. an input column, 2. a function to apply to that column (usually wrapped in `ByRow()`), and 3. the name of the output column ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ``` {.julia .cell-code} transform(penguins, :species => ByRow(x -> x == "Chinstrap") => :is_chinstrap) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=20} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: We can pass multiple columns into an operation as well: ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.julia .cell-code} transform( penguins, [:bill_length_mm, :bill_depth_mm] => (+) => :bill_stuff ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=22} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: This syntax isn't my favorite. Another way to do the same, though, if we wanted: ::: {.cell execution_count=22} ``` {.julia .cell-code} penguins.:bill_stuff = penguins.:bill_length_mm .+ penguins.:bill_depth_mm ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23} ``` 344-element Vector{Union{Missing, Float64}}: 57.8 56.9 58.3 missing 56.0 59.9 56.7 58.800000000000004 52.2 62.2 54.9 55.099999999999994 58.7 ⋮ 61.800000000000004 69.19999999999999 69.0 65.0 71.4 63.3 62.7 75.6 61.6 67.8 69.8 68.9 ``` ::: ::: # Summarizing DataFrames Often, summarizing will involve combining the `groupby()` method with the `combine()` method: ::: {.cell execution_count=23} ``` {.julia .cell-code} # we need to drop missings here on the body mass column first grouped_penguins = groupby(dropmissing(penguins, :body_mass_g), :species) combine(grouped_penguins, :body_mass_g => mean) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=24} ```{=html}
3×2 DataFrame
Rowspeciesbody_mass_g_mean

1Adelie3700.66
2Gentoo5076.02
3Chinstrap3733.09
``` ::: ::: Counting is a common operation: ::: {.cell execution_count=24} ``` {.julia .cell-code} combine(grouped_penguins, nrow) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=25} ```{=html}
3×2 DataFrame
Rowspeciesnrow
String15Int64
1Adelie151
2Gentoo123
3Chinstrap68
``` ::: ::: The problem here is that we've already dropped missing values on body mass, so we're not counting *all* of the observations here. I'm not sure if there's a great way around this inside of `combine()`, but something to explore more... Anyway, say we want to take the mean of all of our numeric columns. We can do that as follows. Note that I don't really like this syntax, especially compared to some of the way you'd do this in `tidyverse` or even in Python's `polars`. It also has the issue that I'm having to keep complete observations rather than column-wise complete data. ::: {.cell execution_count=25} ``` {.julia .cell-code} numeric_cols = names(penguins, Union{Missing,Number}) nomiss_penguins = dropmissing(penguins) grouped_penguins = groupby(nomiss_penguins, :species) species_means = combine(grouped_penguins, numeric_cols .=> mean) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=26} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: We can also perform multiple aggregations on a grouped dataframe, just like we did when we applied multiple transformations via `transform()`: ::: {.cell execution_count=26} ``` {.julia .cell-code} combine( grouped_penguins, :bill_length_mm => mean, nrow => :n ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=27} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # Reshaping data Let's go back to our `species_means` data from before. Say we want to pivot this longer, so that we have a 3-column dataframe where our columns are species, metric, and value. We can do this with the `stack()` function: ::: {.cell execution_count=27} ``` {.julia .cell-code} species_means_long = stack(species_means, Not(:species), variable_name=:metric, value_name=:value) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=28} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: To reshape back to wide, we can use the (appropriately named!) `unstack()` function. This function has the following signature: `unstack(df, id_col, variable_names, variable_values)` So in the example below, species is the id variable, metric is the column with variable names, and value is the column with values. ::: {.cell execution_count=28} ``` {.julia .cell-code} unstack(species_means_long, :species, :metric, :value) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=29} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # Chaining Operations You can chain dataframe operations together in Julia using the `Chain.jl` package. This is basically the same as using the pipe in tidyverse R workflows to set up data processing pipelines. For instance, we can do the following to summarize our data: ::: {.cell execution_count=29} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @chain penguins begin dropmissing groupby(:species) combine(:body_mass_g => mean) end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=30} ```{=html}
3×2 DataFrame
Rowspeciesbody_mass_g_mean
String15Float64
1Adelie3706.16
2Gentoo5092.44
3Chinstrap3733.09
``` ::: ::: The "default" specification of a chain (like above) is to assume the output of the previous function call is the first argument to the subsequent function call. So the output of `dropmissing` -- a dataframe -- is the first argument to `groupby()`, etc. Another way to specify a chain is to use an underscore `_` as a placeholder for the output of the previous expression. This isn't super useful in cases where a dataframe will be the first argument, like below: ::: {.cell execution_count=30} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @chain penguins begin dropmissing(_) groupby(_, :species) combine(_, :body_mass_g => mean) end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=31} ```{=html}
3×2 DataFrame
Rowspeciesbody_mass_g_mean
String15Float64
1Adelie3706.16
2Gentoo5092.44
3Chinstrap3733.09
``` ::: ::: A not-very-useful but nevertheless illustrative version of using an underscore to pipe a value into the not-first argument of a function is below: ::: {.cell execution_count=31} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @chain :body_mass_g begin combine(dropmissing(penguins), _ => mean) end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=32} ```{=html}
